title: The Biden-Trump Presidential Debate
content: JAKE TAPPER, CNN MODERATOR: Weï¿½re live from Georgia, a key battleground state in the race for the White House. In just moments, the current U.S. president will debate the former U.S. president as their partiesï¿½ presumptive nominees, a first in American history. We want to welcome our viewers in the United States and around the world to our studios in Atlanta. This is the CNN presidential debate. DANA BASH, CNN MODERATOR: This debate is being produced by CNN and itï¿½s coming to you live on CNN, CNN International, CNN.com, CNN Max, and CNN Espanol. This is a pivotal moment between President Joe Biden and former President Donald Trump in their rematch for the nationï¿½s highest office. Each will make his case to the American people with just over four months until Election Day. Good evening. Iï¿½m Dana Bash, anchor of CNNï¿½s ï¿½Inside Politicsï¿½ and co-anchor of ï¿½State Of The Union.ï¿½ TAPPER: Iï¿½m Jake Tapper, anchor of CNNï¿½s ï¿½The Leadï¿½ and co-anchor of ï¿½State Of The Union.ï¿½ Dana and I will co-moderate this evening. Our job is to facilitate a debate between the two candidates tonight. Before we introduce them, we want to share the rules of the debate with the audience at home. Former President Trump will be on the left side of the screen. President Biden will be appearing on the right. A coin toss determined their positions. Each candidate will have two minutes to answer a question, and one minute each for responses and rebuttals. An additional minute for follow-up, clarification or response is at the moderatorsï¿½ discretion. BASH: When itï¿½s time for a candidate to speak, his microphone will be turned on and his opponentï¿½s microphone will be turned off. Should a candidate interrupt when his microphone is muted, he will be difficult to understand for viewers at home. At the end of the debate, each candidate will get two minutes for closing statements. There is no studio audience tonight. Pre-written notes, props or contact with campaign staff are not permitted during the debate. By accepting our invitation to debate, both candidates and their campaigns agreed to accept these rules. TAPPER: Now please welcome the 46th president of the United States, Joe Biden. JOE BIDEN, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: How are you? Good to be here. Thank you. TAPPER: And please welcome the 45th president of the United States, Donald Trump. Gentlemen, thanks so much for being here. Letï¿½s begin the debate. And letï¿½s start with the issue that voters consistently say is their top concern, the economy. President Biden, inflation has slowed, but prices remain high. Since you took office, the price of essentials has increased. For example, a basket of groceries that cost $100 then, now costs more than $12; and typical home prices have jumped more than 30 percent. What do you say to voters who feel they are worse off under your presidency than they were under President Trump? BIDEN: You have to take a look at what I was left when I became president, what Mr. Trump left me. We had an economy that was in freefall. The pandemic are so badly handled, many people were dying. All he said was, itï¿½s not that serious. Just inject a little bleach in your arm. Itï¿½d be all right. The economy collapsed. There were no jobs. Unemployment rate rose to 15 percent. It was terrible. And so, what we had to do is try to put things back together again. Thatï¿½s exactly what we began to do. We created 15,000 new jobs. We brought on ï¿½ in a position where we have 800,000 new manufacturing jobs. But thereï¿½s more to be done. Thereï¿½s more to be done. Working class people are still in trouble. I come from Scranton, Pennsylvania. I come from a household where the kitchen table ï¿½ if things werenï¿½t able to be met during the month was a problem. Price of eggs, the price of gas, the price of housing, the price of a whole range of things. Thatï¿½s why Iï¿½m working so hard to make sure I deal with those problems. And weï¿½re going to make sure that we reduce the price of housing. Weï¿½re going to make sure we build 2 million new units. Weï¿½re going to make sure we cap rents, so corporate greed canï¿½t take over. The combination of what I was left and then corporate greed are the reason why weï¿½re in this problem right now. In addition to that, weï¿½re in a situation where if you had ï¿½ take a look at all that was done in his administration, he didnï¿½t do much at all. By the time he left, thereï¿½s ï¿½ things had been in chaos. There was (ph) literally chaos. And so, we put things back together. We created, as I said, those (ph) jobs. We made sure we had a situation where we now ï¿½ we brought down the price of prescription drugs, which is a major issue for many people, to $15 for ï¿½ for an insulin shot, as opposed to $400. No senior has to pay more than $200 for any drug ï¿½ all the drugs they (inaudible) beginning next year. And the situation is making ï¿½ and weï¿½re going to make that available to everybody, to all Americans. So weï¿½re working to bring down the prices around the kitchen table. And thatï¿½s what weï¿½re going to get done. TAPPER: Thank you. President Trump? DONALD TRUMP, FORMER PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES AND CURRENT U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: We had the greatest economy in the history of our country. We had never done so well. Every ï¿½ everybody was amazed by it. Other countries were copying us. We got hit with COVID. And when we did, we spent the money necessary so we wouldnï¿½t end up in a Great Depression the likes of which we had in 1929. By the time we finished ï¿½ so we did a great job. We got a lot of credit for the economy, a lot of credit for the military, and no wars and so many other things. Everything was rocking good. But the thing we never got the credit for, and we should have, is getting us out of that COVID mess. He created mandates; that was a disaster for our country. But other than that, we had ï¿½ we had given them back a ï¿½ a country where the stock market actually was higher than pre-COVID, and nobody thought that was even possible. The only jobs he created are for illegal immigrants and bounceback jobs; theyï¿½re bounced back from the COVID. He has not done a good job. Heï¿½s done a poor job. And inflationï¿½s killing our country. It is absolutely killing us. TAPPER: Thank you. President Biden? BIDEN: Well, look, the greatest economy in the world, heï¿½s the only one who thinks that, I think. I donï¿½t know anybody else who thinks it was great ï¿½ he had the greatest economy in the world. And, you know, the fact of the matter is that we found ourselves in a situation where his economy ï¿½ he rewarded the wealthy. He had the largest tax cut in American history, $2 trillion. He raised ... largest tax cut in history, the largest regulation cut in history. The reason heï¿½s got jobs is because I cut the regulations that gave jobs, but heï¿½s putting a lot of those regulations back on. All of the things that weï¿½ve done, nobodyï¿½s ever ï¿½ never seen anything like ï¿½ even from a medical standpoint. Right to Try, where we can try Space Age materials instead of going to Asia or going to Europe and trying to get when youï¿½re terminally ill. Now, you can go and you can get something. You sign a document. Theyï¿½ve been trying to get it for 42 years. But you know what we did for the military was incredible. Choice for our soldiers, where our soldiers, instead of waiting for three months to see a doctor, can go out and get themselves fixed up and readied up, and take care of themselves and theyï¿½re living. And thatï¿½s why I had the highest approval rating of the history of the V.A. So, all of these things ï¿½ weï¿½re in a failing nation, but itï¿½s not going to be failing anymore. Weï¿½re going to make it great again. BASH: Thank you, former President Trump, President Biden.
